captions.text:
This has nothing to do with physics, but I
want to make a bet with you and 99 other people:

100 in total. You'll all stand in a line,
take a one dollar bill out of your pocket

and write your position in line on the bill.
Then I'll collect the bills, take them to

a separate room, put each one into its own
one of 100 identical boxes, and randomly rearrange
the boxes.

The game is this: each of you come into the
room and try to find which box your bill is

in - but you're only allowed to come in one
at a time, you're only allowed to peek in

half of the boxes, and you aren't allowed
to change anything about the boxes or move

bills around. If you find your own bill, great!
Show me that you've succeeded and then leave

the bill in its box. And regardless of whether
or not you find your bill, you have to leave

the room by a different route so you can't
tell anyone else what you've seen, and the

room is then reset before the next person
comes in.

At the end, if all 100 of you have successfully
found your own bills, you all win and I'll

give each of you a hundred dollars plus the
one you started with! But if any one of you

doesn't find your bill… I keep all the dollars.
You are allowed to plan a strategy together

with the other players before any of you come
into the room, but no communication afterwards.

The question is this: should you take the
bet?

To recap, every person gets to look in half
of the boxes, there's no communication between

players after they go into the room, and you
only win if every single person finds their

own bill. $101 dollar payout if you win, nothing
if you lose.

Take a moment to think about it, then click
the links on screen or in the description

to make your choice - and find out what the
correct answer is.

Basically a person's chance to find his bill is 50/100 = 1/2, the 
requirement to win 100$ is impossible because of chance of the winning is 
1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 * 1/2 * ~ (100 times)
Which results to 1/ 2^100﻿

I wouldn't take the bet. Since the individual searching his bill has no 
more information, the probability that he finds his bill in the 50 boxes 
that he has searched is 1/2 since the bill has to be present in one or the 
other set of 50 boxes. Since the individuals are mutually exclusive, the 
same probability will apply to all. The prob that all of them find the bill 
is the product of individual probabilities. Is 1/2^100 which is a really 
small probability...﻿

Ok so first the bet is worth taking because the risk is not that great 
compared to the reward. 1$ vs 101$. My strategy would be have 50 people 
agree to open the "top" 50 boxes only and the other 50 open the "bottom" 50 
boxes. Each person has a 50/50 shot of finding their bill since they check 
half the boxes. and half of the 100 people's bills are in the "top" 50 
boxes. So if you correctly assign 50 people to the "top" boxes where there 
bills lie you win. The chance is low but still there. And if you have 49 or 
less people check the "top" or "bottom" you automatically lose since 1 or 
more bills is certain to not be found. That's my thoughts anyway.time to 
check the solution lol.﻿

comments.author: Andrew Bird

comments.text:
Without watching the solution video or reading any other comments, here's 
my guess:

No, don't take the bet.  Each person has a 1/2 chance of finding their 
bill.  To find out the probability of two people finding their bills, you 
multiply (1/2)(1/2), which equals 1/4.  To add the probability of a third 
person finding their bill to those two, you multiply the result from the 
last equation by 1/2; (1/4)(1/2)=1/8.  That's the same as (1/2)^3.  From 
there, we can figure out that (1/2)^4=1/16, (1/2)^5=1/32, ect.  So the odds 
of everybody finding their bill is (1/2)^100, which is one in 7.89 times 
10^-31.  So for every 7.89 times 10^31 times that you do this bet, the 
people hiding the bills will win.  Don't take it.﻿

comments.text:
Before you watch the video:

I am going to bet 99 of you: and me, which makes 100.
Each of you will line up in a position from 1 to 100
Take a $1 bill and write the name of your position on it
Then, I will place one bill in each box, also labelled with it's position. 
However, they will be randomly placed, so your bill would not be in your 
box.
Each of you line up and one by one, go into the room with all the boxes.
You are only allowed to look in half of the boxes, which means 50 of them.
If you found your bill, great! place it back in.
Once you are done, you will go out another door, so basically, you can't 
tell your teammates anything afterwards.
I don't explain things clearly, so watch the video anyways.
The question is: will YOU take the bet?﻿

Easy, but it has a 25% or 50% (I think, my Maths are rusty from vacation) 
of working.

#1 goes in and peeks at 50 boxes, hopefully finding the bill. Before 
leaving the room, writes on top of each box which number is the bill 
inside, and leaves.

2# goes in, and looks for the bill. Hopefully finds too. All the boxes are 
now with their bill numbers written on them. If 2# found the bill inside 
one of the written boxes, he will take it, peek at other 49 unwritten boxes 
and writes number on them. The last one gets written upon too by exclusion.

Hurrah, we won.

comments.author: Isaac Kaper

comments.text:
I suppose I had an idea around the same time as Hassan(this is a repost), 
with a similar logic(we both assume that those outside have a watch. 
Feedback?

 If no communication simply means no visual or audible interaction, and the 
next person is called immediately after the successful person leaves the 
room(big assumption), then there is an alternate solution, with a 50% 
chance of winning.
The 100 people line up to go into the room in order. The 1st person(call 
him “A”) goes in the room, and checks the bottom 50 boxes(the 1st half), in 
a snaking order(let’s assume the boxes are in a 10x10 grid). If he finds 
his bill(50% chance), then he leaves at an hour mark representing which box 
he found bill #1, and the minute mark where he found #2, if he found bill 
#2. Ex: Bill #1 found at the 14th box, and bill #2 found at the 45th box, 
so he leaves after 14 hours and 45 minutes. If bill #2 was not found, he 
leaves at 14 hours and 0 minutes. Note: I think he is able to check 50 
boxes even after his own bill is found because in the video it said that he 
left the room when he “[showed him that he had succeeded]”.

Assuming that “A” found the bill, the 2nd person(call him “B”) has a 100% 
chance of finding bill #2.

 Case 1: Say “B” was called into the room at 14:45, then “B” would check 
all of the 1st half for where bill #3 was, and for continuity’s sake, leave 
at hour 45, and the minute marking where he found bill #3. If bill #3 was 
not found, then he would leave at 45:00.

Case 2: Say “B” was called into the room at 14:00, then “B” would check the 
2nd half(top 50, starting from box #51) for where bill #2 was, and leave at 
the corresponding hour marker for that location(let’s say the 13th hour, as 
in the 13th box of the 2nd half), and the corresponding minute marker for 
where bill #3 was found. For example, if bill #3 was found at the 29th 
block, “B” would leave at 13:29 If bill #3 was not found, then “B” would 
leave at 13:00.

“C”, repeats the pattern, and so forth. After each turn, the people in line 
are basically building a coordinate system telling them which bills have 
been claimed (the boxes do not move). After 50 people have repeated these 
steps, people 51-100 can open the remaining 50 unknown boxes to find their 
own bill. 

Yes, you could claim that they couldn't accurately measure the time, but 
it’d be strange for 100 people not to have a watch/phone. Alternatively, we 
could switch hours to days and minutes to half hours, if that would make 
counting easier. ﻿

comments.text:
there is a way to do it, spoiler alert its below

i have not looked at the soulution. me and someone else have worked out the 
solution.
heres your system: first, if you are person x, check box x. then if that 
box didn't have your number, go to the number that is in that box. continue 
this process until you find your bill or you have checked 50 boxes. if we 
pretend you didn't have a 50 box limit, then you would have "cycles" that 
would always lead you back to the box you started at.  in these cycles, the 
box that contains your bill is at the end, because you started at the box 
that bill would lead you to. the chance that a cycle is length y is 1/y 
because of a really long equation i am not going to put in here. therefore, 
the chance that someone don't find your bill is 1/50 + 1/51 + 1/52 + 
1/53... + 1/100. your chances are overwhelming﻿
